head.title: The Wrong Approach To Waste Disposal

hedline.hl1: The Wrong Approach To Waste Disposal

abstract.p: North Fork Environmental Council president Howard Meinke letter on March 2 article holds decision to ship waste across Long Island to Wantagh to be dumped into Atlantic Ocean fails to address serious environmental concerns

block.p: For years the ocean was considered a cheap and convenient waste disposal facility. By river, pipe and barge they poured it in while closing their eyes and holding their noses. Then came Jacques Cousteau, who spent a lifetime demonstrating that the ocean actually is finite and that our carelessness is wreaking destruction at an alarming rate.

Now we read about the socioeconomic arguments concerning the sewage transfer from Great Neck to a treatment plant in Wantagh [''Not in My Sewage Plant,'' March 2] with no serious reference to environmental concerns. We are told the state mandated a 59 percent reduction in the nitrogen being dumped into Manhasset Bay. So now, in the year 2003, we avoid dealing with the problem by shipping the waste across Island to Wantagh and from there to the ocean, where ''the effect of the treated sewage on the South Shore would be less because the ocean currents disperse it faster than in the relatively enclosed space of Long Island Sound.''

For years the ocean was considered a cheap and convenient waste disposal facility. By river, pipe and barge they poured it in while closing their eyes and holding their noses. Then came Jacques Cousteau, who spent a lifetime demonstrating that the ocean actually is finite and that our carelessness is wreaking destruction at an alarming rate.

Now we read about the socioeconomic arguments concerning the sewage transfer from Great Neck to a treatment plant in Wantagh [''Not in My Sewage Plant,'' March 2] with no serious reference to environmental concerns. We are told the state mandated a 59 percent reduction in the nitrogen being dumped into Manhasset Bay. So now, in the year 2003, we avoid dealing with the problem by shipping the waste across Island to Wantagh and from there to the ocean, where ''the effect of the treated sewage on the South Shore would be less because the ocean currents disperse it faster than in the relatively enclosed space of Long Island Sound.''
Once again short-term economics trumps doing the right thing. I had hoped we were smarter than this.
Add this idiocy to our current muddled approach to wetlands preservation, global warming, smokestack emissions and air quality and we should all worry. Is our lease on earth renewable?
Howard Meinke President North Fork Environmental Council
